awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Mobile Phone Based Vital Sign Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project involves the development of an accessible, evidence-based, biofeedback intervention to allow individuals suffering with mental health disorders to have immediate access to effective treatment. A first use case is for the approximately 11% of Americans who experience reoccurring panic attacks, which has significant societal cost such that these individuals are more likely to visit emergency rooms, miss work, and experience subsequent comorbidity. This segment of the population currently has limited access to evidence-based treatment due to long therapy waitlists and often ineffective offerings. The proposed digital therapeutic technology aims to answer this unmet need by providing immediate, inexpensive, evidence-based intervention available on a smartphone. Advances made with this technology could be expanded to also inform biofeedback intervention for other mental health problems including general anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder, substance abuse disorders, and even chronic pain.

This I-Corps project develops new approaches for characterizing physiological states from mobile phone videoes and delivering personalized therapies where and when they are most needed. The novel computational algorithms leverage machine learning to enable accurate estimations of physiological signals that are robust to imperfect data quality inherent in measurements made during daily life.  The technology may also be feasible for use during episodes of high emotional reactivity.  This project builds on innovations in the clinical measurement and intervention by integrating algorithms into a mobile application, using it to collect datasets of real-world suffering and to inform personalized interventions. The feasibility of the tool has been demonstrated as a digital therapeutic for panic attacks.  This project will explore the commercialization potential of this approach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The PanicMechanic team completed the NSF project titled "I-Corps: Mobile Phone Based Vital Sign Detection" during the funding period 7/15/2021-12/31/2022. During our National I-Corp Course (October-November 2021), we completed 101 customer discovery interviews and tested 55 business hypotheses based on our business model canvas. We examined six primary customer segments: emergency room doctors, employers, mental health therapists, university counseling centers, end users who experience panic attacks, and digital mental health companies. We invalidated the first four segments (emergency room doctors, employers, mental health therapists, university counseling centers) and validated the last two (end users who experience panic attacks, digital mental health companies). Through our interviews, a potential business model has emerged wherein our technology is included as a service in other, aggregated digital health offerings. In exploring this path to market, we have developed a deep understanding of current unmet customer needs (engaging user experience, physiology tracking, attack prediction, attack prevention) and partner requirements necessary to enable these integrations (clinical validation, easy integration).

 

During the project period, we secured additional non-dilutive funding that augmented support provided through this award and allowed development of a minimum viable product, PanicMechanic (https://apps.apple.com/us/app/panic-mechanic/id1504526122). This mobile application addresses customer needs for an engaging user experience and the ability to easily track physiology during a panic attack. The app also provides a development foundation from which panic attack prediction and preventative intervention features can be added. These features, identified as key unmet needs during customer discovery interviews, will be enabled thanks to our team's recent advances identifying several candidate markers of panic attack risk that may point toward future preventative interventions. Finally, the app is structured to enable rapid and seamless integration into partner digital health offerings, which addresses a critical requirement identified through our interviews.

 

Next, our team aims to pursue SBIR/STTR and other non-dilutive funding to support continued development of PanicMechanic and its clinical validation along with our academic research partners.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/22/2023
Modified by: Ryan Mcginnis
